results.title: Peach's Australia : Murray Riverboats
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
The Murray River has many problems, including pollution, the dwindling of its native fish, and the introduction of the European Carp, but the biggest problem has been in the threatened loss of its history. To Bill Peach, “the riverboats represent the most colourful and romantic part of that history, and the skeletons of riverboats are symbols of our failure to love and care for our greatest river. Written and presented by Bill Peach.

results.title: Dimensions
results.creator_credit: Bernard Longpre, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film without words (with titles in French) in which simple actions achieve surprising results. A man wants a door in a wall; he draws a rectangle and, presto, there is an opening. In the same way, he conjures up furnishings. If too high or too low, a raising or lowering of a finger puts everything right. The film is a sort of lesson in proportions, which young viewers especially should enjoy. Cast: Paul Buissonneau, Louise Latraverse.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bernard Longpre, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Paws
results.creator_credit: Karl Zwicky, Vicki Watson, Andrena Finlay, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Latent Image Productions, AFFC and PolyGram Film International
results.brief_description: Zac (Nathan Cavaleri) never wanted a dog, until he met a special dog called PC. PC’s master, Alex, is murdered by the evil associates of his ex wife, Anja. Anja and Alex used to live in Iceland where Alex wrote computer programs; the only problem was that Anja stole her husband’s programs and sold them. Alex managed to escape to Australia with 1 million dollars and PC. Before his death Alex attaches a computer disc to PC’s collar and sends him off to a friend. PC ends up in the care of her neighbour, Zac. Through the assistance of a computer which translates dog noises into a human voice, Zac and PC become quickly become friends as they try and avoid Anja and find the 1 million dollars before her. Also starring Norman Kaye, Sandy Gore, Caroline Gillmer, Emilie Francois and Billy Connolly as the voice of PC.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl Zwicky, Vicki Watson, Andrena Finlay, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Latent Image Productions, AFFC and PolyGram Film International

results.title: Pavarotti in London
results.brief_description: The magnificent Luciano Pavarotti performing at his best in a Gala Concert performance at the Royal Albert Hall on 13th April 1982 in the presence of Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, and featuring the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Kurt Herbert Adler. Recorded live on location.

results.title: Pauses
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, Melbourne State College and International Women's Year Committee
results.brief_description: Examines the lives of three successful women who are in their forties. Joyce Nicholson, a writer and business woman, Helen Laycock, a potter and Rosie Smith who runs a craft business. Each describe their work and their experiences as a wife and mother. A useful film discussion starter about woman’s role in Australian society.

results.title: Peace hotel
results.creator_credit: Ka-Fai Wai, John Woo and Cassia Hill Productions
results.brief_description: Chow Yun-Fat is ‘The Killer’, a man famous for having slaughtered a large number of bandits at an inn ten years before. Following the massacre, he ran off to the North-west frontier and established the ‘peace hotel’, a place where anyone can come to seek refuge. The strange order of the hotel is disturbed by the arrival of Shau Siu Man (Cecilia Yip), who is being pursued by a gang. A swindler and a compulsive liar, Shau Siu Man is unable to produce an explanation regarding her situation, but nevertheless begs The Killer to extend hospitality and protection. As the gang gathers around the hotel, the leader delivers an ultimatum to The Killer to surrender the woman or they will storm the hotel. Haunted by remorse over his violent past and lost love, The Killer must decide between risking an all-out war with a determined gang or break his promise of a safe haven to all. ‘Peace Hotel’ is an action-packed take on the (spaghetti) western genre, complete with dust coats and bar brawls, alternating sword fighting sequences with machine gun attacks. Although the plot is at time obscure, elements common to John Woo’s and Chow Yun-Fat’s previous collaborations emerge, such as honour among thieves and the search for redemption. ‘Peace Hotel’ was the last Hong-Kong movie starring Chow Yun-Fat before he embarked on his American career with ‘The Replacement Killers’. It is with ‘All about Ah-long’ the second film for which he is credited as a writer. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: Peace and quiet [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Dave Redman, Daniel Armstrong and Strong Man Pictures
results.brief_description: When the formula to create a super secret agent is stolen from Dr. Genius, it’s left up to special agents Julian Pearce and Frank Quiet to get it back. (Awards: Winner of the Best Special Effects, St Kilda film Festival, 2000, Best Editing in an Australian Film) Cast includes Charles Hollywood and Brian Sisko. Written by Daniel Armstrong.

results.title: Peace Corps in the Majya
results.brief_description: Depicts the work of four Peace Corps volunteers in the Majya Valley of the Niger River. The two young men are an agricultural co-op specialist and a teacher. The young women are public health workers teaching Nigerian mothers to prevent infant mortality. Narrated by George Peppard.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows views across the Melbourne CBD rooftops and steeples, a selection of ‘flowering gums’, a visit to the Botanical Gardens, the arrival of ‘flat tops’ aircraft carrier ships. Kenneth then shows off the neon signs of Melbourne at night.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:20:00 title ‘Melbourne’.

00:00:26:00 views from what appears to be the top of the Royal Melbourne Children’s Hospital in North Melbourne with a note, ‘From Here 178 Feet’ beginning with a view down Elizabeth St toward the CBD.

00:01:06:00 an eastern view, where the Dandenong Ranges can be seen in the distance.

00:01:28:00 to 00:01:37:00 views over Melbourne University toward Queen’s College and the Royal Exhibition Building.

00:01:58:00 a horse and cart enter a city intersection at same time as a tram and cars.

00:02:47:00 Melbourne Technical College rotunda.

00:03:05:00 the Pelaco sign in Richmond (a Heritage Victoria listed landmark). Pelaco is a Melbourne based shirt manufacturing business.

00:30:00:00 Elizabeth St with Flinders St Station in view ends the footage of the rooftops of Melbourne.

00:04:30:00 title card ‘Flowering Gums’ followed by a selection of trees and shrubs in flower.

00:06:52:00 title card ‘Botanical Gardens’ begins a look at people enjoying the gardens. Footage includes examples of fox furs being worn by some women strolling in the gardens.

00:09:28:00 a quick look at what appears to be Captain Cook’s cottage.

00:09:35:00 title card ‘V.A.C.S On Location’ begins a sequence of what appears to be a film being made.

00:10:45:00 title card ‘The Flat Tops Arrive’ footage of large ships (aircraft carriers) and tugboats in the bay viewed by watchers on a small pier near, presumably, Port Melbourne.

00:12:42:00 a plane goes overhead. The sequence ends at at night on the beach. with people overlooking the bay toward the horizon.

00:15:11:00 title ‘Bright Lights’, a sequence at night showing neon signs around Melbourne.

00:16:03:00 the face of Luna Park in St Kilda.

00:16:24:00 Fostor’s Lager advertising sign.

00:16:35:00 Berger Paints (British Paints) advertising sign.

00:16:40:00 to 00:16:55:00 Swallows and Ariells ‘Follow the Swallow’ sequenced advertisement for Uneeda Biscuits, Plum Pudding and Biscuits Cakes Ice cream.

00:16:58:00 Sunshine Milk advertising sign.

00:17:15:00 Ball and Welch department store sign on Flinders St with the T&G Building sign in the background.

00:17:23:00 shows a longer sequence advertisement for Sennets ice cream featuring a bear eating an ice cream.

00:18:00:00 possibly the top dome of the Royal Exhibition Building lit up.

00:18:25:00 ‘Visit the Zoo’ advertising flashes up on screen.

00:19:05:00 advertisement ‘Mascot Underwear for Men and Boys’ featuring a ram and lamb on his back.

00:19:09:00 ‘Dunlop Tyres’ advertising sign.

00:19:33:00 footage ends with blurred city lights and traffic lights turning to red.
